description: Growing data for all crops with timing relative to frost dates

tomato-beefsteak.name: Beefsteak Tomato
tips: Stake or cage plants when transplanting to avoid root damage later
Remove suckers for larger fruits, or leave for more but smaller tomatoes
Water deeply and consistently to prevent blossom end rot
Mulch heavily to retain moisture and prevent soil splash

tomato-cherry.name: Cherry Tomatoes
tips: Very prolific - expect hundreds of fruits per plant
Can be grown in large containers on patios
Harvest when fully colored for best flavor
Plants continue producing until frost

tomato-heirloom.name: Heirloom Tomato
tips: More susceptible to disease than hybrids - good airflow is essential
Flavor is exceptional when vine-ripened
Handle fruits gently as skin is often thinner
Save seeds to continue the variety

tomato-roma.name: Roma Tomato
tips: Determinate variety - fruits ripen within a concentrated period
Excellent for canning and sauce making
Less juicy, more meaty flesh than slicing tomatoes
Good disease resistance

pepper-bell-red.name: Red Bell Pepper
tips: Red peppers are fully ripe green peppers - takes 2-3 weeks longer
Sweeter and more nutritious than green peppers
Support plants once fruits develop to prevent breakage
Pick first fruits to encourage more production

pepper-bell-green.name: Green Bell Pepper
tips: Harvest when full-sized and glossy for crisp texture
Can be picked at any size - smaller peppers are still tasty
Consistent watering prevents bitter taste
Plants are smaller than tomatoes but equally productive

pepper-jalapeno.name: Jalapeno Pepper
tips: Stress (less water) increases heat level
White lines (corking) indicate a hotter pepper
Very prolific - expect 25-50 peppers per plant
Can be harvested green or red (red is sweeter and hotter)

pepper-habanero.name: Habanero Pepper
tips: Needs long warm season - start early indoors
Extremely hot - use gloves when handling
Fruity flavor beneath the heat
Plants are beautiful with colorful fruits

pepper-serrano.name: Serrano Pepper
tips: Hotter than jalapenos, great for salsa
Very productive plants
Best harvested when still green and firm
Thinner walls than jalapenos - not ideal for stuffing

eggplant.name: Eggplant
tips: Loves heat - don't rush transplanting
Harvest when skin is glossy; dull skin means overripe
Cut rather than pull fruits to avoid damaging plant
Flea beetles are common - use row cover early

zucchini.name: Zucchini
tips: Incredibly prolific - 2-3 plants feed a family
Harvest at 6-8 inches for best texture
Check daily - fruits grow quickly
Male flowers appear first, then female flowers with tiny fruit

yellow-squash.name: Yellow Squash
tips: Same care as zucchini
Crookneck and straightneck varieties available
Harvest young for tender skin
Flowers are edible and delicious stuffed

cucumber.name: Cucumber
tips: Consistent watering prevents bitter taste
Trellis vining types to save space and keep fruits clean
Harvest frequently to encourage more production
Morning harvest gives crispest cucumbers

cucumber-pickling.name: Pickling Cucumber
tips: Harvest at 2-4 inches for best pickles
Plants produce in waves - plan succession picklings
Bumpy skin is normal and desirable
Process within 24 hours of harvest for crispest pickles

butternut-squash.name: Butternut Squash
tips: Needs long warm season - start early in short-season areas
Cure in sun for 10 days after harvest for longer storage
Stores 3-6 months in cool, dry conditions
Leave 2-inch stem when harvesting

acorn-squash.name: Acorn Squash
tips: Harvest when skin is hard and deep green with orange spot
Shorter storage life than butternut - use within 2 months
Single-serving size makes portioning easy
Can be baked whole, then scooped

spaghetti-squash.name: Spaghetti Squash
tips: Harvest when skin turns from green to yellow
Stores 1-2 months in cool conditions
Low-carb pasta alternative
Flesh forms spaghetti-like strands when cooked

pumpkin.name: Pumpkin
tips: Count back from desired harvest date to determine planting
Vines spread 15-20 feet - plan accordingly
Place cardboard under fruits to prevent rot
Cure 10 days in sun before storage

watermelon.name: Watermelon
tips: Needs long hot season - use black plastic mulch to warm soil
Thump test: ripe melons sound hollow
Tendril near fruit turns brown when ripe
Reduce watering as fruits ripen for sweeter flavor

cantaloupe.name: Cantaloupe
tips: Ripe when stem slips easily from fruit with light pressure
Strong sweet aroma indicates ripeness
Net pattern becomes more pronounced when ripe
Don't refrigerate until cut for best flavor

honeydew.name: Honeydew Melon
tips: Needs longer season than cantaloupe
Ripe when blossom end gives slightly to pressure
Skin turns creamy yellow when ready
Sweetest when left on vine until fully ripe

lettuce-romaine.name: Romaine Lettuce

fallSow.notes: Fall planting for late fall/winter harvest

tips: Bolt-resistant varieties extend harvest in warm weather
Harvest outer leaves for extended picking
Afternoon shade helps in hot weather
Succession plant every 2 weeks for continuous harvest

lettuce-butter.name: Butter Lettuce
tips: Tender leaves bruise easily - handle gently
Buttery, mild flavor
Harvest whole head or cut-and-come-again
Best in cooler weather

lettuce-mixed.name: Mixed Salad Greens
tips: Cut at 4-6 inches, will regrow 2-3 times
Mix includes variety of colors and textures
Great for containers and small spaces
Sow densely for baby greens

spinach.name: Spinach

fallSow.notes: Fall planting for winter harvest or overwintering

tips: Prefers cool weather - bolts quickly in heat
Plant in fall for overwintered spring harvest
High in iron and nutrients
Baby leaves are more tender

kale.name: Kale

fallSow.notes: Fall planting for winter harvest - frost sweetens flavor

tips: Frost improves flavor - becomes sweeter
Harvest lower leaves first, plant keeps producing
Can overwinter in many zones
Multiple varieties: curly, lacinato, red Russian

swiss-chard.name: Swiss Chard
tips: Colorful stems are edible and decorative
More heat tolerant than spinach
Harvest outer leaves for continuous production
Can produce for entire growing season

arugula.name: Arugula
tips: Fast growing - from seed to salad in 4 weeks
Peppery flavor intensifies in heat
Let some plants flower for edible blooms
Self-seeds readily for future crops

collard-greens.name: Collard Greens
tips: Southern staple - extremely cold hardy
Frost sweetens the leaves
Harvest lower leaves, plant keeps producing
Can survive temperatures into the teens

mustard-greens.name: Mustard Greens
tips: Spicy, peppery flavor - milder when young
Very fast growing
Bolts quickly in heat - plant in spring or fall
Seeds can be saved for making mustard

microgreens.name: Microgreens
tips: Grow year-round indoors on windowsill
Harvest when first true leaves appear
Concentrated nutrition - 4-40x more nutrients than mature plants
Popular varieties: sunflower, pea shoots, radish, broccoli

carrot.name: Carrots

fallSow.notes: Fall carrots sweeten after light frost

tips: Loose, sandy soil prevents forking
Keep soil moist during germination (up to 3 weeks)
Thin to 2-3 inches apart when tops are 2 inches tall
Fall carrots are sweetest after light frost

beet.name: Beets

fallSow.notes: Fall planting for late fall harvest

tips: Each seed cluster produces multiple plants - thin to one
Greens are edible and delicious
Harvest when golf ball to tennis ball size
Golden varieties don't bleed like red ones

radish.name: Radishes
tips: Fastest vegetable to harvest - 3-4 weeks
Succession plant every week for continuous harvest
Becomes woody and pungent if left too long
Great for marking rows of slow-germinating seeds

potato.name: Potatoes
tips: Plant certified seed potatoes, not grocery store potatoes
Hill soil around stems as plants grow
New potatoes ready when plants flower
Cure in dark for 2 weeks before storage

sweet-potato.name: Sweet Potatoes
tips: Grown from slips (rooted sprouts), not seed potatoes
Needs long warm season - 90+ frost-free days
Harvest before first frost
Cure at 80-85Â°F for 10 days for best storage

turnip.name: Turnips
tips: Both roots and greens are edible
Best flavor from fall harvest
Quick growing - good for succession planting
Harvest when 2-3 inches diameter

parsnip.name: Parsnips
tips: Needs frost to convert starches to sugar
Can overwinter in ground with mulch
Very slow germination - 3-4 weeks
Use fresh seed only - viability drops quickly

onion-yellow.name: Yellow Onion

fallSow.notes: Short-day onions (Vidalia, Texas Sweet) for zones 7+

tips: Day length determines bulbing - choose correct variety for latitude
Short-day onions (Vidalia) planted fall in zones 7+ for spring harvest
Stop watering when tops fall over
Cure in sun for 1-2 weeks before storage

onion-red.name: Red Onion
tips: Milder flavor than yellow onions
Great for fresh eating in salads
Shorter storage life than yellow varieties
Color fades when cooked

green-onion.name: Green Onions / Scallions
tips: Can regrow from root ends in water or soil
Harvest by pulling or cutting at soil level
Bunching varieties don't form bulbs
Succession plant for year-round harvest

garlic.name: Garlic
tips: Plant in fall for summer harvest
Separate bulbs into individual cloves for planting
Cut scapes (curly tops) to encourage larger bulbs
Harvest when lower leaves brown, tops still green

leek.name: Leeks
tips: Hill soil around stems for longer white portion
Very cold hardy - harvest into winter
Mild onion flavor, no bulb formation
Excellent in soups and stews

shallot.name: Shallots
tips: Plant sets (small bulbs) like garlic cloves
Each set multiplies into cluster of 4-12 shallots
Gourmet mild flavor prized by chefs
Store like onions after curing

broccoli.name: Broccoli

fallSow.notes: Start indoors mid-summer for fall transplant

tips: Harvest main head before flowers open
Side shoots continue producing for weeks after main harvest
Prefers cool weather - bolts in heat
Fall crop often easier than spring

cauliflower.name: Cauliflower
tips: More finicky than broccoli - needs consistent conditions
Blanch white varieties by tying leaves over head
Purple and orange varieties don't need blanching
Single harvest per plant - no side shoots

cabbage-green.name: Green Cabbage
tips: Very cold hardy - improves flavor after frost
Consistent watering prevents head splitting
Early varieties 70 days, storage varieties 100+ days
Excellent for sauerkraut

cabbage-red.name: Red Cabbage
tips: Same care as green cabbage
Color intensifies in acidic conditions
Keeps color when pickled or fermented
High in antioxidants

brussels-sprouts.name: Brussels Sprouts
tips: Frost dramatically improves flavor
Harvest bottom sprouts first as they mature
Top the plant 3 weeks before harvest for uniform sprouts
Long season - plant for fall/early winter harvest

kohlrabi.name: Kohlrabi
tips: Harvest when tennis ball size - larger gets woody
Swollen stem (not root) is the edible part
Mild, slightly sweet flavor like broccoli stem
Fast growing - good for succession planting

bok-choy.name: Bok Choy
tips: Baby bok choy ready in 30 days
Bolts quickly in heat - grow in spring or fall
Both leaves and stems are edible
Great for stir-fries and salads

green-beans.name: Green Beans
tips: Bush beans don't need support; pole beans need trellis
Pick frequently to encourage more production
Inoculant helps fix nitrogen in soil
Don't work in beds when leaves are wet - spreads disease

snap-peas.name: Sugar Snap Peas
tips: Plant as early as soil can be worked
Provide trellis - most varieties climb 4-6 feet
Entire pod is edible and sweet
Heat ends production - enjoy spring harvest

snow-peas.name: Snow Peas
tips: Harvest when pods are flat, before peas develop
Dwarf varieties available for small spaces
Tendrils and shoots also edible
Classic in stir-fries

shell-peas.name: Garden Peas
tips: Shell fresh peas immediately for best sweetness
Sugars convert to starch quickly after picking
Blanch and freeze for year-round enjoyment
Kids love eating them straight from the pod

lima-beans.name: Lima Beans
tips: Need warm soil - don't rush planting
Pole varieties more productive than bush
Harvest when pods are plump but still green
Also called butter beans

edamame.name: Edamame
tips: Harvest when pods are plump, still bright green
Entire plant produces at once - not continuous
Boil in salted water for classic preparation
High in protein - great vegetarian option

basil.name: Basil
tips: Pinch flower buds to prolong leaf production
Harvest from top to encourage bushy growth
Classic partner for tomatoes in garden and kitchen
Many varieties: sweet, Thai, lemon, purple

cilantro.name: Cilantro
tips: Bolts quickly in heat - succession plant every 2 weeks
Seeds (coriander) are also culinary herb
Slow-bolt varieties extend harvest
Self-seeds readily for next year

parsley.name: Parsley
tips: Slow to germinate - soak seeds overnight
Biennial - flowers second year
Cut outer stems to encourage new growth
Flat-leaf has stronger flavor than curly

mint.name: Mint
tips: VERY invasive - plant in containers or with barriers
Spreading roots can take over entire garden beds
Many varieties: spearmint, peppermint, chocolate, apple
Cut back hard to rejuvenate

rosemary.name: Rosemary
tips: Mediterranean native - needs excellent drainage
Overwatering is the main killer
Bring indoors where winters are cold
Can live for decades in mild climates

thyme.name: Thyme
tips: Very hardy once established
Prefers lean, dry conditions
Harvest before flowering for best flavor
Many varieties: lemon, caraway, creeping

oregano.name: Oregano
tips: Greek oregano has strongest flavor
Cut back after flowering to maintain shape
Dries very well for winter use
Spreads readily - can become aggressive

sage.name: Sage
tips: Beautiful silvery foliage - ornamental as well as culinary
Don't overwater - prefers dry conditions
Prune woody growth in spring to rejuvenate
Classic with poultry and stuffing

dill.name: Dill
tips: Doesn't transplant well - direct sow only
Both leaves (dill weed) and seeds are flavorful
Self-seeds prolifically
Essential for pickles and fish dishes

chives.name: Chives
tips: Perennial that returns stronger each year
Purple flowers are edible and beautiful
Cut to 2 inches above ground to harvest
Divide clumps every 3-4 years

lavender.name: Lavender
tips: Needs excellent drainage - raised beds ideal
Don't overwater or over-fertilize
Harvest flowers just before fully open
Prune in spring to maintain shape

lemongrass.name: Lemongrass
tips: Tropical plant - bring indoors before frost
Can grow 3-6 feet tall
Harvest outer stalks at base
Root stalks from grocery store in water

strawberry.name: Strawberries
tips: June-bearing: one large harvest; everbearing: crops all season
Remove flowers first year for stronger plants
Runners can be rooted for new plants
Mulch heavily for winter protection

blueberry.name: Blueberries
tips: MUST have acidic soil - most gardens need amendment
Plant 2+ varieties for cross-pollination
Takes 2-3 years to produce significant harvest
Net plants to protect from birds

raspberry.name: Raspberries
tips: Summer-bearing vs everbearing varieties
Prune after fruiting to maintain productivity
Spreads via underground runners
Very productive once established

blackberry.name: Blackberries
tips: Thornless varieties available for easier harvest
Train on trellis or fence
Can become invasive if not managed
Prune after harvest - new canes fruit next year

grape.name: Grapes
tips: Needs sturdy trellis or arbor support
Heavy pruning essential for fruit production
Takes 3 years to first real harvest
American, European, and hybrid varieties for different climates

apple.name: Apples
tips: Plant 2+ varieties for pollination
Dwarf rootstocks for smaller trees
Annual pruning essential
Takes 4-7 years to first fruit

pear.name: Pears
tips: Harvest when still firm, ripen off tree
Less maintenance than apples
Fire blight can be serious issue
Asian pears ripen on tree, European off tree

peach.name: Peaches
tips: Need 600-900 chill hours depending on variety
Self-fertile - one tree sufficient
Thin fruit to 6-8 inches apart for larger peaches
Prune heavily - fruits on 1-year wood

plum.name: Plums
tips: European plums often self-fertile; Japanese need pollinators
Less prone to pests than peaches
Prunes are dried Italian plums
Thin fruit for larger plums

cherry.name: Cherries
tips: Sweet cherries need pollinators; sour often self-fertile
Bird netting essential
Short harvest window - pick when fully colored
Rain during harvest causes splitting

fig.name: Figs
tips: Can grow in containers and overwinter indoors
Wrap or protect in cold climates
Self-pollinating - one tree is enough
Two crops possible in warm climates

lemon.name: Lemons
tips: Frost-sensitive - zones 9-11 outdoors only
Meyer lemons best for containers
Bring indoors where winters are cold
Fruit year-round once established

lime.name: Limes
tips: More cold-sensitive than lemons
Key limes best for containers
Thornless varieties available
Harvest when green for most lime flavor

orange.name: Oranges
tips: Need consistent warmth - zones 9-11
Navel for eating, Valencia for juice
Fruit may stay on tree for months
Dwarf varieties good for containers

corn.name: Sweet Corn
tips: Plant in blocks, not rows, for pollination
Heavy feeder - needs nitrogen
Silks dry and brown when ready
Sugars convert to starch quickly - eat same day

asparagus.name: Asparagus
tips: Perennial that produces for 20+ years
Don't harvest first 2 years
Harvest in spring for 6-8 weeks
Let ferns grow to feed roots for next year

rhubarb.name: Rhubarb
tips: Only stalks edible - leaves are toxic
Don't harvest first year
Pull (don't cut) stalks for harvest
Needs winter cold to produce well

artichoke.name: Artichokes
tips: Perennial in mild climates, annual elsewhere
Needs vernalization (cold period) to flower
Harvest buds before they open
Large, dramatic plants - good focal point

celery.name: Celery
tips: Very demanding - needs constant moisture
Blanch by mounding soil or wrapping
Slow growing but worth the effort
Harvest outer stalks as needed

fennel.name: Fennel
tips: Don't plant near other vegetables - can inhibit growth
Bulb fennel vs herb fennel are different
Bolts in heat - plant for spring or fall
Anise flavor mellows when cooked

okra.name: Okra
tips: Loves heat - don't rush planting
Soak seeds overnight for better germination
Harvest at 3-4 inches - larger pods get tough
Pick every 2-3 days for continuous production

sprouts.name: Sprouts
tips: No soil needed - just water and a jar
Rinse 2-3 times daily
Popular: mung bean, alfalfa, broccoli, radish
Refrigerate and eat within a week

flowers-edible.name: Edible Flowers
tips: Popular: nasturtiums, pansies, calendula, borage
Never eat flowers treated with pesticides
Harvest in morning after dew dries
Add color and flavor to salads and desserts

flowers-cut.name: Cut Flowers
tips: Popular: zinnias, sunflowers, dahlias, cosmos
Cut in early morning for longest vase life
Cut more for more blooms
Succession plant for season-long bouquets

notes.timingExplanation: All timing is relative to last spring frost date unless otherwise noted. Negative weeks = before frost, positive = after.

frostTolerance.high: Very cold hardy, can survive temps below 20Â°F

notes.perennials: Berries and tree fruits focus on care/harvest timing rather than planting from seed. Days to maturity represents time to first significant harvest.
notes.tropicalNote: For tropical regions, crops marked tropicalSuitable:false may not grow well due to lack of cold period or excessive heat.
